title: 107_hr4513
content: The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Protection Act of 2002". The Congress finds that the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers contributes to illegal activities like fraud and identity theft, leading to privacy invasions and violent crimes. Financial institutions and other entities using these numbers for identity confirmation can inadvertently facilitate criminal activities. The sale or purchase of Social Security numbers can lead to criminal activities and privacy invasions. The Federal Government requires individuals to have a Social Security number for tax purposes, benefits, and employment, but this requirement has inadvertently made these numbers tools for crime and fraud. The Federal Government's requirement for individuals to have Social Security numbers for tax, benefits, and employment has inadvertently made these numbers tools for crime and fraud. It is necessary for the Government to take steps to prevent the abuse of this system. The Government needs to address the abuse of Social Security numbers, as they do not convey any meaningful information or facilitate public debate. (5) Social Security numbers do not contain significant information or concern public issues. The sale of these numbers does not promote public debate, and restrictions on their sale would not impact public discourse. (6) Profiting from the sale of Social Security numbers should not put individuals at risk of harm. (7) Congress should pass legislation to protect individuals with these numbers. Congress should enact legislation to protect individuals from the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers to prevent harm. The legislation aims to protect individuals by preventing the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers. In this Act, the term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission, "person" means any individual or entity, and "sale" involves exchanging a Social Security number for something of value, excluding government benefit applications. The term "purchase" in the Act refers to exchanging anything of value for a Social Security number, excluding government benefit applications. The Computer Matching and Privacy Protection Act defines "purchase" as exchanging anything of value for a Social Security number, excluding government benefit applications. The term "State" refers to any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the United States Virgin Islands. The definitions of "Social Security number" and "Social Security account number" are provided in section 208 of the Social Security Act. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and any U.S. territory or possession. SEC. 4. REGULATION OF THE SALE AND PURCHASE OF SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBERS AND SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBERS. Prohibition on selling or purchasing Social Security numbers in violation of regulations promulgated by the Commission. Regulations will restrict the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers and account numbers to prevent unfair or deceptive practices. The Commission will promulgate regulations to restrict the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers and account numbers, preventing unfair or deceptive practices. Restrictions imposed will be no broader than necessary to ensure the security of these numbers. The Commission will regulate the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers to prevent fraud and harm to individuals. Restrictions will be tailored to ensure security without being overly broad. The Commission will regulate the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers, considering harm, benefits, and relevant factors. Exceptions include law enforcement, national security, and public health purposes. The sale and purchase of Social Security numbers and account numbers are regulated by the Commission, with exceptions for law enforcement, national security, public health, emergency situations, and research purposes. Research conducted for advancing public knowledge may use Social Security numbers with assurances that they will not be used to harass or reveal identifiable individuals. Research conducted for advancing public knowledge may use Social Security numbers with assurances that they will not be used to harass, target, or publicly reveal information about identifiable individuals. Researchers must also ensure that information obtained will not be used to make decisions affecting specific individuals and have safeguards in place to protect privacy and confidentiality. The researcher must have safeguards in place to protect the privacy and confidentiality of identifiable individuals, including obtaining voluntary written consent for the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers. Other appropriate circumstances will be determined by the Commission. The Commission must promulgate regulations within 1 year of enactment to protect the privacy of individuals, including the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers. Other circumstances will be determined by the Commission. The Commission must promulgate regulations within 1 year of enactment to protect privacy, including Social Security numbers. Violations of these regulations will be treated as violations of Federal Trade Commission regulations. Effective dates for the regulations will be 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. The regulations issued under this section will be enforced by the Commission as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts or practices. The Commission will prevent violations of this section and its regulations in the same manner as other regulations. The Commission will enforce regulations under this section to prevent violations, with the same powers and duties as the Federal Trade Commission Act. Violators will face penalties and entitlements as per the Act. Any person who violates regulations under this Act will be subject to penalties and entitled to privileges and immunities as per the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission's authority is not limited by this Act. The Act does not limit the Commission's authority under other laws. States can take civil actions on behalf of their residents if they believe a violation of Commission regulations has occurred. The State, as parens patriae, may bring a civil action in a district court of the United States to enjoin, enforce compliance, or obtain damages on behalf of residents if a violation of Commission regulations has occurred. The State, as parens patriae, can bring a civil action in a US district court to enforce compliance with regulations, obtain damages, restitution, or other relief on behalf of residents, with prior notice to the Commission and Attorney General. Before filing an action under this subsection, the State attorney general must provide written notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission and the Attorney General. If providing notice before filing is not feasible, it should be done as soon as possible after the complaint is filed. Commission and attorney general have authority in this matter. The State attorney general must provide written notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission and the Attorney General promptly after filing. Upon receiving notice, the Commission and Attorney General have the right to move to stay the action or intervene in a pending Federal matter. The State attorney general must provide notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission and the Attorney General after filing. The Attorney General can intervene in a pending Federal matter, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal in criminal proceedings or civil actions for violations of the Act. (C) Pending criminal proceedings.--During any criminal or civil action initiated by the Attorney General or Federal Trade Commission for a violation of this Act, no State can bring a separate action against the same defendant for the same violation. The Act prohibits states from initiating separate civil actions against defendants named in criminal or civil proceedings for violations of the Act. State attorneys general can still conduct investigations and compel witnesses under their state laws. Any action under this section can be brought in any district court of the United States meeting venue requirements under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code.
